title: Is a computer a mechanical machine? - Quora

response.answer_text: It could be. There is nothing in the idea of a “computer” that couldn’t be done mechanically. However current computers are not mechanical machines - they are electronic machines with few (if any) moving parts. Mechanical computers have been designed and built. Charles Babbage famously designed one called “The Analytical Engine” - and actually built some parts of it. There is a replica of one of his earlier computing machines in the London Science Museum - and it actually works quite well. There have also been thoughts of using nanotechnology to build computers out of tiny pushrods, gears and levers just a few dozen atoms long. Such machines would (by virtue of their TINY size and three-dimensional form) be able to be vastly more complex, much faster and more energy efficient than present day computers. However, none of those have yet been built. I actually own a small mechanical computer (you can read about it here: Digi-Comp I - Wikipedia). They were sold for $5 as educational toys back in the 1960’s. It’s not much of a computer though. It can add together two numbers (so long as they’re both smaller than 3) and it can play a game of “Nim”…which isn’t bad for a bunch of cardboard, bent wire and elastic bands!  But it’s stretching a point to call it a “computer” at all.

Good question, set me thinking anyway. Looking at the machine I’m doing this on I’d say it’s electrical/electronic and mechanical. Mostly the bits of it are solid state, so there’s no moving parts but I am severely inconveniencing a great many electrons. However, there’s a big fan whirring round in it which, though controlled and driven by electricity, is a moving part and sits on mechanical bearings. The hard drive is not solid state and relies on precision parts moving in unison to read and write to a platter coated with magnetic properties, and that platter is spinning. That’s definitely mechanical. The keyboard I’m doing this with has buttons that depress to make contact with an electrical membrane and come back up again by means of a spring and you can’t get more mechanical than that. All the plugs and wires depend on a friction fit into their respective ports apart from the VGA cable which is held in place by a couple of screws and screws are an ancient mechanical device. So given that I’d be inclined to say electrical/mechanical hybrid.
